summary: Adenoid cystic carcinoma (ACC) is a rare type of cancer that can occur in various body sites, most commonly in the salivary glands. It is the third-most common malignant salivary gland tumor overall and the most common malignant salivary gland tumor in the submandibular gland region. ACC is generally well-differentiated and slow-growing, allowing patients to survive for years with metastases, though late-occurring metastatic disease can lead to death.
causes: MYB gene fusion with the NFIB gene due to t(6;9) translocation
MYB activation by copy number gain
MYB activation by juxtaposition of enhancer elements near the MYB gene
Fusion of the MYBL1 gene to NFIB or other partners
diagnosis: MRI-images analyzed following nerve tracts up to the brainstem
treatments: Fast neutron therapy (for advanced, inoperable, recurrent, or gross residual disease)
Chemotherapy (for metastatic disease, on a case-by-case basis)
